channel.title: Server Connection ---> Client?
channel.description:
Ok so im a quite good coder my self but my brother is like a master at Java programming so I got him to try make a server with me and he wants to know, What is the file to find this "Connection".
Example\Brothers question: When the users clicks somewhere on the map and it moves what does it send to the server? And do the servers work of UDP or TCP?

item.title: Server Connection ---> Client?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

If you look into existing server bases (preferably scratch built, clean ones) you can learn all of this information.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Connection ---> Client?
item.dc:creator: @Shadowspkin Shadowspkin
item.description:
@Shadowspkin wrote:

[quote=“jmood128, post:4, topic:393028”][quote author=Shadowspkin link=topic=490199.msg3584512#msg3584512 date=1304048996]
Brother:
So is there any “standard” to communicating with the client from the server. My brother mentions servers such as 614, 317, etc… To they all share some sort of “standard” for communicating with the client? I will look around for the tutorials… but most of what I’ve come across is for people who know nothing about java… I know how to create UDP and TCP connections… just not sure how the server should communicate with the client.

EDIT: Are there Javadocs for servers?
[/quote]

Most scratch servers are documented.

It sounds like your asking about incoming and outgoing packets? sent by the server and client?[/quote]

Yes thats what im asking.Were would a find a TuT on transferring datagrams etc?

@'SJ_ To bad famous people dont reply.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Connection ---> Client?
item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

I thought UDP and TCP were ports for opening up your server
And I thought either, UDP or TCP worked. I also believe there is a documentation or something like that around here.

Edit:
http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/socket-140484.html
Possibly what you’re looking for?

Read full topic
